title: Tamim Ahsan
text:
I am a PhD Candidate at the School of Science, University of Wollongong, New South Wales, Australia. Currently, I am also affiliated with the University of Sydney (Australia), the Max Planck Institue of Psychiatry (Germany) and the National Institute of Biotechnology (Bangladesh).
My PhD project adopts a spatially resolved single-nucleus multimodal approach to delineate stress-induced molecular changes in the brains of psychiatric patients.
In addition to science, I love poetry, music, philosophy and paintings. I believe that the universe offers no inherent meaning for us, but we can face this absurdity of life by undertaking creative endeavors.
So, I started this blog to write about science, mostly neuroscience and computational biology, and to post my literary works. I just wanted to create a space where my thoughts can flow without any hindrance and thus help discover, improve and then rediscover myself.
To know more about me and my work, please consider visiting my website by clicking on the link that says Website on the top right corner of this page.
Thank you for visiting my blog! I really appreciate your support. If you like what I write, please recommend it to a friend. Should you have any feedback or comment, please do not hesitate to get in touch with me via email or social media.

title: A dark, lonely night
text:
In the stillness of this cold night,
a half-eaten moon hangs from the sky.


As I walk through the road
beset with long trees on both sides
and look up,
I glimpse a scantly lighted sky,
and patches of clouds are floating by.


Far away,
there is an inhuman groan
that clings to darkness like a shadow
and dreams to devour us all.


When I reach an open field though,
a flood of stars suddenly appears.


For although my face is numb from coldness,
my eyes and whatever is left of human in me
still seek light,
even on this dark, lonely night.

title: We are not alone
text:
At a vantage point,
at the top of a mountain,
though our views are often blocked
by clouds or mists,
we never stand alone.


On our shoulders,
and on our neck,
the touch and the breath of those who are gone
always declare their presence
although we sometimes fail to feel.


And in this valley of choices and chances,
the past screams and the future waves,
we must both scream and wave back.



Context
This poem highlights the necessity to acknowledge the coexistence of our past memories and our future prospects.
We tend to define our lives in terms of the choices we make and the opportunities we get. Although we are obsessed with the idea of constant progress and the contemplation of what the future might offer, we often ignore the efforts and sufferings of our ancestors. By failing to acknowledge the roles of our forefathers in shaping both our present and future, we lose an essential part of our identity. Our existential crisis majorly arises from this negligence.
I once read somewhere that sustainable development is simply the act of making progress without reducing the future generations’ chances of survival. 
Thus, sustainability and harmony can never be achieved until we choose to become a continuation of yesterday which will smoothly flow into the landscape of tomorrow.

title: Sequencing-based Spatial Transcriptomic Platforms
text:
Single-cell omics approaches have revolutionized the field of molecular and cellular biology by endowing us with the ability to capture cellular heterogeneity. Although these approaches can help identify biological process-associated cell-states, as well as cell-type-specific molecular patterns, they involve a cell dissociation step which causes the loss of spatial information.

Delineating the spatial context of a cell-state or cell-type is essential for fully dissecting its role in health and disease. Therefore, a series of spatial omics technologies are now being developed.

In 2026, I expect my PhD project to make substantial use of spatial transcriptomics datasets to elucidate the cell-type- and region-specific molecular alterations associated with stress in the brains of psychiatric patients. Therefore, I will need to improve my understanding of the data generation and analysis methods.

Undoubtedly, one of the best ways to deepen one’s knowledge is to write about the topic of interest as much as one can. With that in mind, I have decided to regularly post about spatial transcriptomic technologies and data analysis methods. I am starting this journey with a poster briefly showing examples of sequencing-based spatial transcriptomic (sST) approaches that adopt various spatial indexing strategies. My future blog posts will explore data analysis workflows step by step.

title: Lonely cage
text:
In this lonely cage,
there are diamonds and gold coins,
but not enough air.





“In this lonely cage”
Within any capitalist society, the majority of human interactions are transactional in nature. Climbing up the “career ladder” takes precedence over holding the hands of a fellow human being with nothing but affection. As a result, we all become increasingly lonely and isolated despite building large, professional networks. This feeling of loneliness and separation breeds paranoia and anxiety, that surround us like a cage. There is no escape from this entrapment.



“there are diamonds and gold coins”
Unchecked capitalism rapidly creates income inequality, which leads to widening wealth gap. However, for those who are members of the “bourgeoisie”, it offers wealth (diamonds) and investment opportunities (gold coins). We are told that there are plenty of resources for all hardworking individuals to become rich. Believing this myth, we have willingly chosen to call “the cage” our home. Liberty and freedom merely become concepts found only in books on philosophy.



“but not enough air”
“The cage”, although full of glittering wealth, lacks the basic elements (air) we need to survive. So, the competition for survival becomes intense. Those with power and money easily crush any newcomers, making it difficult for anyone to “make it big” only through diligence and hard work. That is why, the top tier of our hierarchical society is largely populated by those who inherit substantial amount of properties, while the rest of us are being crushed under the weight of mounting living costs. The concept of equal opportunity is no longer valid.
